title: FIDO Specification
description: The Funeral Interchange Data Object (FIDO) is a JSON format designed for data exchange between various stakeholders involved in the funeral process.

Appointment.description: A document related to a funeral case. Some examples are a death notification ("Sterbefallanzeige" in German), an order confirmation, a bill or a memorial card ("Trauerkarte" in German). A document consists of a name and a file, optionally including preview images.

Name.description: Title of the appointment, e.g. "Trauergottesdienst" (German for funeral service).

Type.description: Purpose of the appointment. If none of the available options applies, omit this property and just use a descriptive "Name".

StartDate.description: Date and time, when the appointment begins.

EndDate.description: Date and time, when the appointment ends. Optional.

Location.description: Description of the location, e.g. "St. Peter's Church".

Document.description: A document related to a funeral case. Some examples are a death notification ("Sterbefallanzeige" in German), an order confirmation, a bill or a memorial card ("Trauerkarte" in German). A document consists of a name and a file, optionally including preview images.

Name.description: The name of the document, e.g. "Sterbefallanzeige" for a death notification in a German funeral case. The possible names are not defined within the FIDO format due to the vast variety arising from national and even regional differences.

FileName.description: The file belonging to this document, referenced by file name. The file is stored in the Files property in the root object.

Previews.description: Optionally, the list of preview images for this document. For example, there could be a JPG preview of page 1, and a PNG preview also for page 1 and for page 2.

DocumentPreview.description: A preview image of a document.

Page.description: Optionally, the page number of the preview, starting with "1". If the document is a single sheet with an inner and outer side, like for a memorial card, also the values "Inside" and "Outside" can be used here.

FileName.description: The file content, referenced by file name. The file is stored in the Files property in the root object.

File.description: A file attached to the funeral case, e.g. a document in PDF format, a photo in JPG format, or any other file type.

Name.description: File name, with extension, but without a path. For example "Condolence Card.jpg". Should be unique within the list of files to make it possible to reference this file.

MimeType.description: Media type of the file, as defined in https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml . For example "application/pdf" for a PDF file or "image/jpeg" for a JPEG image. May be omitted if unknown or for custom file formats, like funeral software specific formats.

Type.description: Specifies how the file is encoded in the Data property.

Data.description: File content or source, as specified in the Type property.

Identification.description: Funeral case ID within a specific software program.

Software.description: Name of the software, e.g. "Funeral App Pro".

Id.description: ID of the funeral case in this software. The format is specific to this software, and could be a number or any string, e.g. "00356", "SF-2023-0188", "Mustermann, Max, 2023-07-06" or a UUID.

Person.description: Information about a person. Use only the fields which make sense in the context of the person.

Roles.description: List of roles of this person in the funeral case. The most important role is the deceased person. Not each involved person needs to have a role, but some persons may have multiple ones (e.g. both contact person and payer).

Relationship.description: Relationship of this person to the deceased.

Title.description: Academic or professional title, like "Prof. Dr." as a German example.

FirstName.description: Forename(s) of the person. In case of multiple forenames, separate by spaces.

PreferredName.description: In German naming conventions, it is common for individuals to have multiple given names, and the preferred name ("Rufname") refers to the name by which a person is primarily addressed or known in everyday life. It is the preferred or familiar name used by family, friends, and colleagues, as distinguished from the individual's other given names.

PlaceOfBirth.description: Location, most often the city, where the person was born.

DateOfDeath.description: Date of decease of the person.

PlaceOfDeath.description: Location, most often the city, where the person died.

CauseOfDeath.description: Circumstances that led to this person's demise. In local language.

Citizenship.description: Nationality of the person. Use a ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 code, like "DE" for Germany. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2"

Profession.description: Job of the person, or last job of the deceased. In local language.

Religion.description: Religion. May be a code in a national context like "r.k." for Roman Catholic in Germany.

SocialInsurances.description: List of social insurances known for this person.

SocialInsurance.description: The social security system is different for each country. In this format, we store the name of the program and a number identifying the person within this program.

Name.description: The localized name of the social security system, e.g. in German "Krankenversicherung" (health insurance) or "Rentenversicherung" (pension insurance).

Number.description: The number which identifies the person within this system. For example, a pension insurance number in Germany would look like "33 160894 W 098".

FormatName.description: Must contain "FIDO" to mark this object as a FIDO object.

FormatVersion.description: Version number of the FIDO format used in this object. The current version number is "0.1".

Identification.description: The same funeral case may have different IDs in the used software components. In this data structure, the ID of each involved software is stored. This allows each application involved in the funeral process to identify the funeral case in its own database when it comes back from another software. Each software may add its own ID here, but should never change the ID of other programs.

Persons.description: The list of all persons, including the deceased.

Appointments.description: The list of all appointments in this death case.

Documents.description: The list of documents, e.g. a death notification or a memorial card.

Files.description: The list of attached files, e.g. documents, photos or cards. To optimize performance, consider placing this property as the last one in the JSON object when storing large raw data. This strategy allows the reading software to access important information quickly or abort processing if necessary.
